paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to pressed metal tile roofs.
paragraph.commentary: Additional guidance on pressed metal tiles can be found in the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice.

paragraph.title: Installation
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

paragraph.title: Tiles and accessories
paragraph.p: Tiles and their accessories shall meet the requirements of NZS 4217.

subparagraph.title: Choice of metal
subparagraph.commentary: The exposure zone in which a building is located can affect the durability of flashings. Exposure zones are defined in NZS 3604, based on the likely exposure to wind-driven sea-salt. Corrosion due to geothermal or corrosive industrial atmospheres, as defined in NZS 3604, require specific design. Exposure zones are based on AS/NZS 2728. AS/NZS 2728 lists atmospheric classes derived from ISO 9223 for Australia and New Zealand.

subparagraph.title: Steel
subparagraph.p: Steel for the manufacture of pressed metal tile and flashing systems shall:

ol.li: have a base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.39 mm minimum,
be grade G300 or G250,
be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.

subparagraph.p: Paint coatings may include factory-applied finishes complying with AS/NZS 2728, or factory-painted or bonded resin and chip finishes of minimum 15 year durability.

subparagraph.title: Aluminium
subparagraph.p: Aluminium for the manufacture of pressed metal tiles and flashing systems shall comply with AS/NZS 1734, and shall:

ol.li: Have a base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.7 mm minimum,
Be minimum 5000 series,
For pre-painted aluminium, have a factory-applied finish complying with AS/NZS 2728.

paragraph.title: Roof pitch
paragraph.p: General approximations of profile types for standard profile and shake or shingle profile metal roof tiles are shown in Figure 32.
The minimum roof pitches for metal tiles where rafter length does not exceed 12 m shall be limited to:

ol.li: 12° (1:4.75) for profiles resembling standard profiles, and
15° (1:3.75) for profiles resembling shingle or shake profiles.

paragraph.p: Where rafter length exceeds 12 m, increase minimum pitch by 1° per additional 0.5 m.
paragraph.commentary: Panels are available in a wide range of profiles. Where manufacturers have more stringent requirements, these should be followed to optimise performance and to avoid invalidating guarantees.

paragraph.title: Underlay
paragraph.p: All metal tile roofing shall have a roof underlay installed. Roof underlay shall be to Table 23. Refer to Paragraph 8.1.5 for installation details.
If LOSP-treated timber is used, roof underlay shall not be applied until the LOSP solvent has been allowed to evaporate.
paragraph.commentary: Solvent in freshly LOSP-treated timber can affect bitumen in underlays. Any solvent should be allowed to evaporate before the roof underlay is installed.

paragraph.title: Fixings
paragraph.p: Pressed metal tiles shall be fixed as shown in Figure 33, with:

ol.li: 50 x 2.8 mm hot-dipped galvanized painted flat-head annular-grooved nails. For fixings through the top of the tiles, use neoprene washers containing no more than 15% by weight carbon black content, with

li.p: Four fixings per sheet through:

ol.li: the turn-down of the tiles for the body of the roof, and
the top of the profile slope for sheets at the eaves, avoiding the weather channel of the tiles.

paragraph.title: Flashings
paragraph.p: The roof shall be flashed at all boundaries, except at the discharge to a gutter, using the details shown in Figure 34 to Figure 37.
Metal flashings are generally supplied by the metal tile manufacturer, and shall comply with Paragraph 8.3.4.2 and Table 7, unless specifically shown otherwise in the details.
paragraph.commentary: Metal tile manufacturers supply pre-folded or formed accessories and recommendations for their installation.

figure.title: Ridge or hip flashings for metal tile
Eaves and barge for metal tile
Hidden and valley gutter flashings for metal tile

paragraph.title: Gutters, ridges, barges and fascias
paragraph.p: Gutters, ridges, barges and fascias shall be as shown in Figures 34-37. Refer to Paragraph 5.2 for termination of roofs against wall claddings.

paragraph.title: Roof penetrations
paragraph.p: Pipe penetrations shall be flashed using EPDM flashings similar to that shown for masonry tiles, Figure 29.
paragraph.commentary: Use purpose-made preformed rooflights and ventilators supplied by the manufacturer of the tiles where available.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following types of profiled metal roof cladding:

ol.li: Profiled as outlined in Paragraph 8.4.4,
Valley gutters that do not change direction in plan,
Not curved, and
With sheets no more than 18 metres long.

paragraph.commentary: If curved profiled metal sheet is used, the radius of the curve may affect durability. Specific design is required, and manufacturers and the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice should be consulted for recommendations.

paragraph.title: General
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

subparagraph.title: Choice of metal
subparagraph.p: Metal roof cladding and flashings shall be selected according to the exposure conditions in Table 20 as defined in:

ol.li: NZS 3604, or
AS/NZS 2728.

subparagraph.commentary: The exposure zone in which a building is located can affect the durability of flashings. Exposure zones are defined in NZS 3604, based on the likely exposure to wind-driven sea-salt. Corrosion due to geothermal or corrosive industrial atmospheres, as defined in NZS 3604, require specific design. Exposure zones are based on AS/NZS 2728. AS/NZS 2728 lists atmospheric classes derived from ISO 9223 for Australia and New Zealand.

subparagraph.title: Steel
subparagraph.p: Materials for the manufacture of profiled steel roof cladding shall:

ol.li: have a BMT of 0.4 mm minimum
be grade G550, or G300 for rolled, crimped, or trough profile roofing
be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.

subparagraph.title: Aluminium
subparagraph.p: Aluminium for the manufacture of profiled aluminium roofing shall comply with AS/NZS 1734, and be a minimum:

ol.li: Base metal thickness (BMT) of 0.7 mm,
5000 series.

subparagraph.p: Pre-painted aluminium roofing shall have a factory-applied finish complying with AS/NZS 2728.
subparagraph.commentary: A deterioration in the appearance of the coating of the metal does not necessarily relate to a deterioration in the weathertightness of the roof cladding.

paragraph.title: Profiles
paragraph.p: Profiles covered in this Acceptable Solution are shown in Figure 38, and consist of:

ol.li: Corrugated - curved with a crest height of 16.5 mm minimum,
Trapezoidal - symmetrical or asymmetrical with a minimum crest height of 19 mm, and for asymmetrical a flat or lightly profiled pan width of 210 mm maximum between crests, and
Trough profile - with vertical ribs at a minimum height of 38 mm, and flat or lightly profiled pans of 210 mm maximum between crests.

paragraph.title: Roof pitch
paragraph.p: For roofs up to 18 metres in length without end laps, pitches shall be:

ol.li: Corrugated - not less than 8° (1:7).

li.p: Trapezoidal - not less than:

ol.li: 4° (1:14) where the crest height is less than 27 mm, or
3° (1:20) where the crest height is 27 mm or higher.
Trough profile - not less than 3° (1:20).

paragraph.commentary: For roofs over 18 metres in length refer to the manufacturer for minimum pitch requirements. Where manufacturers have more stringent requirements, these should be followed to optimise performance and to avoid invalidating guarantees.

paragraph.title: Structure
paragraph.p: The maximum span and fixing patterns of profiled metal roof cladding between purlins to comply with this Acceptable Solution are given in Table 11, Table 12 or Table 13, 14 and 15. Spans shown are for steel with BMT, grade and profile as specified in each Table.
paragraph.commentary: For purlin sizes, spacing and fixing, refer to NZS 3604. Additional support will be required around roof-mounted services such as air-conditioning in order to avoid roof distortion.
It is recommended that access to the roof is limited to within 100 mm of purlin lines to avoid damaging the roof cladding.

paragraph.title: Underlay
paragraph.p: All profiled metal long-run roofing shall have a roof underlay installed to Table 23. See Paragraph 8.1.5 for installation details.

paragraph.title: Fixings: corrugated and trapezoidal
paragraph.p: Fixings shall be as shown in Tables 11, 12, 14 and 15, and shall be a minimum 12-gauge screw, as shown in Figure 39, which complies with Class 4 of AS 3566: Part 2.
paragraph.commentary: Screw fixing is recommended for metal roofing as there is less likelihood of the fixing ‘backing out’ than with a nail. The spacing requirements for fixings are conservative, and a specific design may produce a more optimum spacing, especially with the use of load-spreading washers. Consult roofing manufacturers for information.

subparagraph.title: Fixing requirements
subparagraph.p: Fixings shall:

ol.li: Be fixed through crests,
Penetrate purlins by a minimum of 40 mm for nail fixings and 30 mm for screw fixings,

li.p: Include sealing washers of:

ol.li: neoprene (having a carbon black content of 15% or less by weight),
profiled washer and EPDM washer where required to allow for expansion of the profiled metal roof cladding.

figure.title: Corrugated and trapezoidal fixings and sheet lap

paragraph.title: Fixings: trough profile
paragraph.p: Clip fixings for trough profiles and spans as shown in Table 13 shall be as shown in Figure 40, and shall:

ol.li: Have a minimum BMT of 0.9 mm
Be a minimum width of 30 mm
Be made from a material compatible with the cladding, refer to Tables 20 and 21
Have clips fastened with a minimum of two 10-gauge by 30 mm waferhead hot-dipped galvanised screws which comply with Class 3 of AS 3566: Part 2.

paragraph.title: Allowance for expansion
paragraph.p: Allowance shall be made for expansion of corrugated and trapezoidal roof cladding as shown in Table 16.
Where Table 16 requires profiled washers, allowance shall be made for expansion by:

ol.li: Fixing the top 50% (closest to the ridge) with conventional fixings, and

li.p: Fixing the lower 50% with sealing washers fixed over profiled washers as shown in Figure 39, and:

ol.li: using oversized holes, and
positioning fixing in centre of hole.

paragraph.title: Flashing requirements
paragraph.p: The roofing shall be flashed at all boundaries to comply with the following:
paragraph.li: At edges discharging to gutters with eaves flashings where required in Figure 45(a)
Soft edge to cover flashings complying with Paragraph 4.6. Refer to Figure 41 for example of use and Tables 21 and 22.
Notched turn-downs to cover flashings shall comply with Paragraph 4.6. Refer to Figure 42 for example of use.
Materials for flashings shall be compatible with the roof cladding material as per Table 21 and Table 22, and shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.3.
Provide expansion joints in accordance with Paragraph 4.5.2.

subparagraph.title: Fixing flashings
subparagraph.li: When fixing flashings to the structure, use screws as for roofing (see Paragraph 8.4.8).

li.p: When fixing flashings to other flashings or to roofing use:

ol.li: for galvanized steel, 4 mm diameter monel metal or stainless steel rivets, where compatible as per Table 21,
for aluminium-zinc coated steel, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets,
for aluminium, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets.

subparagraph.commentary: The use of stainless steel fixings is not recommended by steel manufacturers for use with coated steel, in severe marine and industrial environments, as they are considered to cause deterioration.
subparagraph.li: Flashing joins, including expansion joints where required, shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.5.2 and as shown in Figure 6.

li.p: Where end-laps are required in flashings, form these as shown in Figure 6 and, before joining the two parts, apply an 8 mm diameter bead of neutral cure sealant complying with:

ol.li: Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or
low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.

paragraph.title: Flashing details
paragraph.p: The roof shall be flashed using details shown below:

ol.li: Ridge to hip as shown in Figure 43,
Apron flashing and change in pitch as shown in Figure 44,
Eaves and roof/wall ridge as shown in Figure 45,
Eaves flashing as in Figure 45(a) required for all roofs under 10¼ pitch and soffit widths less than 100 mm,
Ridge and hip as shown in Figure 46,
Barge flashings as shown in Figure 47,
Apron flashing - parallel flashing to profile as shown in Figure 48.

paragraph.commentary: Reduced cover for barge and apron flashings may be applicable for specifically designed roofs in low wind zones. Refer to the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice for additional guidance on ridge to hip flashings.

figure.title: Apron flashing and change in pitch for profiled metal
Eaves and roof/wall ridge for profiled metal
Ridge and hip flashings for profiled metal
Parallel apron flashings for profiled metal

paragraph.title: Stopends
paragraph.p: The top ends of profiled metal roof cladding shall have stopends as shown in Figure 49 for trapezoidal and trough profile metal roof cladding, where:

ol.li: The roof pitch is less than 25°, or
The building is in a High/Very High/Extra High wind zone.

paragraph.title: Turn-downs at gutters
paragraph.p: The lower ends of trapezoidal and trough profile roofing shall be turned down at gutters, where the roof pitch is less than 10°. The turn-down shall be 30° from the plane of the sheet.
paragraph.commentary: Specific tools are available and should be used to turn up or turn down ends. Care should be taken to ensure the sheet does not split. Refer to the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice for guidance on methods.

paragraph.title: Profile closure
paragraph.p: Preformed compressible seals shall not be used at the eaves.
paragraph.commentary: Refer to the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice for guidance.

paragraph.title: Hidden, valley and internal gutters
paragraph.p: Hidden, valley and internal gutters shall be in accordance with Paragraph 8.1.6.

subparagraph.title: Hidden gutters
subparagraph.p: Parallel hidden gutters shall be as shown in Figure 50 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.

subparagraph.title: Valley gutters
subparagraph.p: Valley gutters shall be in accordance with catchment areas shown in Table 8, and as shown in Figure 51 and Paragraph 8.1.6.2.
subparagraph.commentary: Refer to the New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice for additional guidance on sizing, materials and fixing.

subparagraph.title: Internal gutters
subparagraph.p: Internal gutters shall be as shown in Figure 52 and Paragraph 8.1.6.1.

figure.title: Parallel hidden gutter for profiled metal

paragraph.title: Roof penetrations
paragraph.p: The maximum length of profiled roof cladding above penetrations shall be as shown in Table 17. The edge of roofing penetrations over 200 mm wide shall be supported in either direction with additional framing as shown in Figure 21.
Roof penetrations shall be flashed as follows:

ol.li: Pipe penetrations up to 85 mm shall be flashed using an EPDM boot flashing as shown in Figure 53,
Pipe penetrations up to 500 mm shall be flashed using a soaker flashing and EPDM boot flashing as shown in Figure 54,
Rectangular penetrations up to 1200 mm wide shall be flashed using a soaker type flashing as shown in Figure 55.

paragraph.commentary: Penetrations on lower pitched roofs, larger penetrations, or needing specialised complex flashings will require specific design to suit the particular circumstances. The New Zealand Metal Roof and Wall Cladding Code of Practice should be consulted for guidance.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to membranes composed of butyl or EPDM installed over plywood substrates for:
paragraph.li: Roofs with a minimum fall of 2° (1:30),

li.p: Decks with:

ol.li: a minimum fall of 1.5° (1:40),
a maximum area of 40 m2,
no steps in level within deck area except into gutters,
no integral roof gardens, and
no downpipe direct discharge to deck,

paragraph.li: Internal gutters with a minimum fall of 1 in 100, with no cross seams in the gutters, and
Decks with removable raised surfaces to give level access as shown in Figure 17A.
paragraph.p: The application of directly applied wearing or decorative surfaces to membranes is not covered in this Acceptable Solution.
paragraph.commentary: EPDM and butyl rubber membranes are subject to damage when on trafficable roof-decks. A suitable wearing surface will help reduce such damage. Increases in slopes from the previous version recognise deflection tolerances in NZS 3604 and in-service loadings by building owners.

paragraph.title: General
paragraph.p: Closed-in construction spaces under membrane roofs and decks require adequate ventilation to prevent the accumulation of moisture under the membrane. Maintain a minimum gap of 20 mm between the underside of the substrate and any insulation, and for membrane roofs greater than 40 m2, refer to manufacturer's details for roof cavity vents and/or substrate vent requirements.
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

paragraph.title: Plywood substrates
paragraph.p: Plywood shall be:

ol.li: A minimum of 17 mm complying with AS/NZS 2269,
At least CD Grade Structural plywood with the sanded C face upwards, and
H3 with treatment type compatible with membrane and adhesives used, and kiln dried after treatment.

paragraph.commentary: The compatibility of LOSP-treated timber must be checked with membrane suppliers. If using plywood containing copper-based preservatives, check the compatibility of adhesives and membranes with copper with the product manufacturers.

paragraph.title: Butyl and EPDM
paragraph.p: Butyl rubber and EPDM rubber sheet and system components used for membrane roofing or decks shall:

li.p: Be a minimum thickness of:

ol.li: 1 mm for roofing, or
1.5 mm for decks, and

li.p: Refer to Paragraph 8.1.6.1 for membranes to gutters
Comply with the following parts of Table 1 in ASTM D6134:

ol.li: tensile strength,
elongation,
water absorption,
water vapour permeance, and
heat aging followed by: a. tensile strength b. elongation, and

li.p: Have adhesives, primers, seam tapes and pre-formed components where supplied by the manufacturer that:

ol.li: comply with BRANZ EM 5, and
are part of a complete system approved by the manufacturer or supplier of the membrane.

subparagraph.title: Plywood
subparagraph.p: Substrates must be dry when membranes are applied. The plywood and timber substructure must be a maximum moisture content of 20% when a membrane is adhered.
subparagraph.commentary: This will generally require substrates to be covered to prevent rain wetting, or to be pre-primed to avoid moisture uptake. Manufacturers' recommendations should be consulted, as some require a lower moisture content in order to validate guarantees.
subparagraph.p: Plywood substrates shall be fixed according to the following requirements:

ol.li: Panels shall be laid with staggered joints (brick bond),
Panels shall be laid with the face grain at right angles to the main supports,
Supports in b) shall be at 400 mm maximum centres,
The edge of sheets shall be supported with dwangs or framing,
External edges shall be chamfered with a minimum radius of 5 mm,
A 20 mm H3.2 triangular fillet shall be used at the base of any 90° upstand, and

li.p: Shall be fixed:

ol.li: with 3 mm gaps between all sheets,
using 10 g x 50 mm stainless steel countersunk head screws,
at 150 mm centres on edges, and
at 200 mm centres in the body of the sheets.

subparagraph.title: Butyl and EPDM
subparagraph.p: Seam tapes shall be used on all joints of:

ol.li: Roofs or decks with falls less than 5° (1:12),
Penetrations through the membrane where butyl or EPDM flashing is required,
EPDM membrane, and
Butyl membranes that contain EPDM.

subparagraph.commentary: Coloured butyl membranes contain EPDM, which makes them more difficult to adhere properly. Seams should be aligned parallel to the fall of the deck to minimise ponding. Where a penetration is made through the membrane subsequent to laying, the flashing should be installed by the applicator of the membrane system.
subparagraph.p: All joints in the plywood and junctions of plywood with other materials shall have 25 mm polyethylene release tape applied before application of the membrane.

paragraph.title: Roof and deck drainage
paragraph.p: Membrane roofs and decks shall be constructed to provide:

ol.li: Falls as shown in Figure 56 and details in Figures 57-64
A minimum of 100 mm below an adjoining threshold as shown in Figure 62
Membrane upstands against all walls, parapets, or enclosed balustrades extending to a minimum level of 150 mm above deck level as shown in Figure 62.
ol.commentary: If the clearance of the cladding from the deck or roof surface is at the minimum of 35 mm, give an overlap of 115 mm to the cladding.

li.p: Water discharging either:

ol.li: into a roof or gutter outlet with a minimum diameter of 75 mm as shown in Figure 64 with either: an overflow as shown in Figure 63 (c) or an extra outlet, with both outlets sized to take the full required capacity. or,
via a scupper, into a gutter, or rainwater head, as shown in Figure 63 (a), (b) and (d).
Gutters formed with continuous butyl or EPDM strip complying with Paragraph 4.3.9, with no cross-joints.

figure.title: Falls in membrane roofs and decks

paragraph.commentary: Refer to E1/AS1 for specific drainage requirements outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution. Seams in gutters are particularly difficult to form at outlets through enclosed balustrade walls, and the risk of failure is high. Failure of a seam can result in damage to underlying walls.

paragraph.title: Control joints
paragraph.p: All control joints in the substrate shall be accommodated in the membrane roof design. The design of control joints for membrane roofing is subject to specific design and is outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.

paragraph.title: Junctions
paragraph.p: All junctions of roof or deck to walls, parapets and enclosed balustrades shall be made weathertight using the following appropriate details:

ol.li: Figure 57: External corner in upstands,
Figure 58: Internal corner in upstands,
Figure 61: Verges and eaves,
Figure 62: Junctions of decks and walls, and
Drainage details to Paragraph 8.5.6.

subparagraph.title: Junctions with walls
subparagraph.p: Junctions of membrane decks or walls shall be formed as shown in Figure 62. The bottom of the wall cladding above the deck or roof surface shall be sealed prior to fixing.

paragraph.title: Penetrations
paragraph.p: Penetrations through membrane roofs and decks shall be as shown in Figure 59 and Figure 60.

subparagraph.title: Handrails
subparagraph.p: Fixing of posts for handrails into membrane roofs or decks is not covered by this Acceptable Solution.
subparagraph.commentary: Any fixing of posts into membrane roofs or decks will require specific design. The fixing of posts into tiles over a membrane is particularly risky, and should be avoided.

paragraph.title: Gutters
paragraph.p: Deck gutters and internal outlets shall be constructed as shown in Figure 64.
paragraph.commentary: Internal outlets should have a dome-type cover to reduce risk of blockage, except where this could constitute a pedestrian hazard.

figure.title: Rainwater head and scupper opening in membrane

section.title: General
section.p: Wall claddings shall meet the requirements of NZBC E2.3.2 to E2.3.7, and comply with the provisions of Paragraph 9.1.1 to Paragraph 9.9.
Claddings in Extra High wind zones require:

ol.li: Rigid underlays to Paragraph 9.1.7.2
Drained cavities to Paragraph 9.1.8
Hooks and hems on flashing upstands, and additional 25 mm height to Paragraph 4.6.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the wall cladding systems listed in Paragraph 3.3. Table 3 lists wall cladding systems that shall be used for buildings with varying risk scores. The method of establishing the level of risk associated with the use of a specific wall cladding is given in Paragraph 3.1. Based on this risk score, a wall cladding may require the inclusion of a drained cavity as described in Paragraph 9.1.8. Claddings in Extra High wind zones require rigid underlays and drained cavities - refer to Table 3.

paragraph.title: Maintenance
paragraph.p: Maintenance of wall claddings shall be carried out as necessary to achieve the expected durability of the material - refer to Paragraph 2.5.

paragraph.title: Bottom of cladding
paragraph.p: Separations, clearances to ground level, and overlaps shall be as shown in Figure 65 and Table 18. Clearances to roof claddings and decks shall be minimum 35 mm - refer to Table 7 and Figure 18.
Clearances shall be measured to:

ol.li: The finished plane of any adjacent horizontal surface, or
The top surface of any adjacent sloped or horizontal apron flashing.

paragraph.commentary: This keeps the bottom edge of the cladding dry, and allows cleaning and painting of the bottom surfaces.

subparagraph.title: Concrete slabs
subparagraph.p: Slab levels shall be set to allow reinstatement of final landscaped ground levels as outlined in Figure 65 and Table 18.
subparagraph.commentary: NZS 3604 may require greater ground clearances depending on floor type and materials. The likely final landscaped ground levels are to be taken into account when planning foundations and earthworks to avoid reductions to the minimum ground clearances in the finished building.

subparagraph.title: Masonry veneer clearances
subparagraph.p: The height of the floor slab above finished ground level shall be in accordance with Figure 73D and as shown in Table 18.

subparagraph.title: Bottom of wall claddings for concrete ground slabs (except masonry veneer)
subparagraph.p: At concrete slab level, the base of the cladding system shall be as shown in Table 18, and:

li.p: Finish a minimum of:

ol.li: 100 mm above a paved surface, or
175 mm above finished unpaved surface,
Overlap the concrete slab by 50 mm, and
Be offset horizontally by a minimum of 6 mm for direct fixed claddings to prevent capillary action.

subparagraph.title: Garages and openings to garages
subparagraph.p: Refer to Figure 65 and Table 18 for overall level change requirements.
subparagraph.commentary: This paragraph does not apply to garages that are detached outbuildings.
subparagraph.p: Garage spaces within, or attached to, the building envelope shall have:

ol.li: Openings provided with a 50 mm minimum total level change between the interior and the exterior paving,
ol.commentary: Methods for achieving the required step may include: A 50 mm difference in finished ground level adjacent to the opening, or A raised threshold at the opening, or Concrete nibs at the opening.
ol.li: Provision to drain water away from the threshold of the opening
Rigid wall underlays, to Table 23, where external garage walls are unlined
linings to garage walls adjoining habitable spaces
weather resisting garage doors
window and door details (where included) to Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9.

subparagraph.title: Bottom of wall claddings for timber floor framing
subparagraph.p: Suspended timber floors shall meet the requirements of NZS 3604. Clearances from paved and unpaved surfaces to the wall framing shall be in accordance with NZS 3604, and Table 18.
At ground floor level, the base of the cladding system shall:

ol.li: Overlap the timber floor structure by 50 mm minimum, and
For walls with direct fixed claddings, be offset horizontally from a concrete foundation wall by a minimum of 6 mm
Have no direct connection between sub-floor spaces and drained cavities.

subparagraph.commentary: Where claddings require drained cavities, care must be taken to ensure air from the subfloor space cannot enter the cavity. This is important, as moisture levels in subfloor air can be high.

paragraph.title: Barriers to airflow
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution requires external walls to have barriers to airflow, in the form of:

ol.li: Interior linings with all joints stopped for wind zones up to Very High, or
Rigid underlays (and drained cavities) for buildings in Extra High wind zones - refer to Paragraph 9.1.7.2
Where walls are not lined, such as attic spaces at gable ends, an air barrier complying with Table 23, fixed to framing prior to fixing cladding or cavity battens
For attached garages, underlays to Paragraph 9.1.3.4.

paragraph.commentary: The primary function of air barriers and air seals is to moderate airflows at junctions and inside the wall cavity. Airflows in certain weather conditions encourage significant amounts of water to move along their path, and it is therefore important to manage airflow in cavity walls with barriers and air seals. In the absence of internal linings, an air barrier is required to support wind pressures at locations such as gable ends and unlined garage spaces. Air pressure drop is not always across the internal lining, indicating the wall underlay acts as an air barrier as well.

paragraph.title: Wall underlays to wall openings
paragraph.p: Prior to window or door installation:

ol.li: Flexible wall underlay shall be cut and dressed into all sides of openings as per Figure 72A and B,

li.p: Flexible flashing tape shall be applied to head and sill framing as shown in Figures 72A and 72B. Flexible flashing tape shall

ol.li: comply with Parts 3.2 and 4 of ICBO Acceptance Criteria AC148, and
be compatible with the wall underlay

paragraph.commentary: Dressing the wall underlay around the framing timber and providing a flexible air seal limits airflows around the window reveal. The flexible flashing tape keeps any water that does get past the cladding, or through the joinery, from direct contact with the timber.

paragraph.title: Air seals
paragraph.p: Window, door and other penetration openings shall be provided with flexible air seals to minimise the risk of airflows carrying water into the building wall. The air seal shall be:

ol.li: Provided between the reveal or frame and the wrapped opening (for example of use, refer to Figure 81),
Installed over a closed cell polyethylene foam (PEF) backing rod, or similar

li.p: Made of:

ol.li: self-expanding polyurethane foam, or
sealant complying with: a. Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or b. low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.

paragraph.commentary: Some sealants can react with bitumen based flashing tape, preventing full curing of the sealant. Where necessary, consult sealant manufacturers for application requirements. Backing rods are used for sealant and for self-expanding polyurethane foam as there is a danger foam will expand to the outside of the wall and form a moisture bridge to the interior. For further information refer to ASTM C1330 for backing rod material performance.

subparagraph.p: Flexible wall underlays shall be in accordance with Table 23, and shall:

ol.li: Be run horizontally,
Have upper sheets lapped over lower sheets to ensure that direction of laps will allow water to be shed to outside of the wall underlay,
Be lapped not less than 75 mm at horizontal joints,
Be lapped not less than 150 mm over studs at vertical joints, and
Extend 35 mm below bottom plate or bearer,
Be restrained from bulging into a drained cavity. Refer to Paragraph 9.1.8.5.

subparagraph.p: Rigid wall underlays, in association with drained cavities (including direct fixed corrugated profiled metal), are required in Extra High wind zones. Refer to Table 3 and Table 23. Rigid underlays are also required to external walls of attached garages that are unlined. Refer Paragraphs 1.1.1 and 9.1.3.4 c).
Rigid wall underlays shall be in accordance with Table 23, and shall:

ol.li: Be minimum 7 mm H3 plywood, or 6 mm fibre cement sheet
Be installed with sheet edges fixed over solid framing
Be over-fixed with a flexible wall underlay from Table 23 and installed as in Paragraph 9.1.7.1
ol.commentary: Some proprietary systems may not require the addition of a flexible underlay
ol.li: Have flexible underlay folded into opening reveals as in Paragraph 9.1.5 a)
Have cavity battens at maximum 600 mm centres
Be finish flushed with underside of bottom plate or bearer.

subparagraph.commentary: External air pressures in higher wind zones can transfer to interior linings, and exceed recommended loadings prescribed by some lining manufacturers. Rigid underlays will protect linings from undue air pressure loadings, and help ensure cavity depths are maintained for the proper functioning of the drained cavity.

paragraph.title: Drained cavities
paragraph.p: Based on the risk score for an external wall calculated as per Paragraph 3.1, a wall cladding may require the inclusion of a drained cavity. Where a drained cavity is required, it shall meet the requirements of Paragraphs 9.1.8 to 9.1.9.4.
paragraph.commentary: Cavities manage occasional ingress of water past the cladding, but should not act as gutters or drains.

subparagraph.title: Limitations
subparagraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to systems where:

ol.li: Cavity battens are fixed, by the cladding fixings, to the wall framing,
Claddings are fixed through the cavity battens into the wall framing, and
The drained cavity behind claddings, except in masonry veneer, is not vented at the top.

subparagraph.p: Systems where the cladding is fixed into the cavity batten only are outside the scope of this Acceptable Solution.

subparagraph.title: Requirements
subparagraph.p: Where a drained cavity is required, it shall:

li.p: Be installed over a wall underlay, either flexible or rigid, that:

ol.li: complies with Table 23, and
is fixed to wall framing,
Be formed using vertical cavity battens,

li.p: Restrict air movement between the drained cavity and:

ol.li: floor, wall and roof framing,
attic roof space, and
subfloor space,
Be drained and open to the exterior at the bottom of cavities,
Use vermin-proofing at the cavity base as per Paragraph 9.1.8.3 and Figure 66,

Use cavity spacers as shown in Figure 67, where fixing is required between cavity battens. Alternative cavity spacers to those described in Paragraph 9.1.8.2 are permitted. Refer to Paragraph 9.1.8.4 f).

subparagraph.commentary: Solid horizontal cavity spacers risk obstruction of air flow in cavities and risk bridging moisture across the cavity.

subparagraph.title: Vermin-proofing
subparagraph.p: Vermin-proofing shall be provided above window and door heads and at the base of the drained cavity. Figure 66 provides one example of an appropriate cavity closer. Aluminium, stainless steel or uPVC in accordance with Paragraph 4.1 shall be used where vermin-proofing material is not readily accessible or replaceable.
Vermin-proofing shall:

ol.li: Provide holes or slots between 3 mm and 5 mm,
Provide an area of opening of 1000 mm2 per lineal metre of wall, and

li.p: Be positioned to allow a minimum drip edge to the wall cladding of:

ol.li: 10 mm at the base of walls, and
15 mm above window and door head flashings.

subparagraph.commentary: It is important the openings in vermin-proofing are kept clear and unobstructed in order to maintain draining and venting of the cavity. The closure shown is only one option for vermin-proofing. Provided openings are as specified, other dimensions can vary, so allowing the use of other shapes such as channels and right-angles.

subparagraph.title: Cavity battens and jamb battens
subparagraph.p: Cavity battens shall:

ol.li: Be nominal 20 mm (between limits of 18 mm and 25 mm in thickness),
Be a minimum 45 mm wide,
Be fixed, by the cladding fixings, through the wall underlay into the framing,
If timber, comply with B2/AS1,
If polystyrene, comply with Paragraph 9.9.3.1, and be protected from any incompatible vapours from timber treatment.
ol.p: Cavity battens and/or cavity spacers that meet E2/VM1 Class 1 testing and B2/AS1, permit air circulation are allowed. The Class 1 test must include a horizontal cladding joint supported on a cavity spacer batten of a proposed type. Jamb battens shall:
ol.li: be nominal 20 mm (between limits of 18 mm and 25 mm in thickness), minimum 45 mm wide, and of timber complying with B2/AS1. Refer to Figure 72A.

subparagraph.commentary: The solvents from freshly LOSP-treated timber may melt polystyrene, so these should not be used together. Solid horizontal cavity spacers risk obstruction of air flow in cavities and risk bridging moisture across the cavity. Battens will be fixed by the cladding fixings, which will penetrate the wall framing. Battens will therefore need only temporary fixing until the cladding is fixed. Polystyrene battens may be temporarily adhered to the wall underlay.

subparagraph.title: Wall framing behind cavities
subparagraph.p: Dwangs shall be at a maximum of 1350 mm centres generally and maximum 480 mm centres for direct-fixed vertical weatherboard profiles, and vertical metal corrugated and symmetrical trapezoidal claddings.

Where stud spacings are greater than 450 mm, and flexible wall underlays only are used, an intermediate means of restraining the flexible wall underlay and insulation from bulging into the drained cavity shall be installed. Acceptable means of achieving this are by using:

ol.li: 75 mm galvanized mesh or wire galvanized in accordance with AS/NZS 4534,
Polypropylene tape or galvanized wire at 300 mm centres fixed horizontally and drawn taut, or
Vertical cavity battens at 300 mm centres maximum.

paragraph.title: Penetrations

subparagraph.title: Penetrations through cavities
subparagraph.p: Window penetrations through cavities shall meet the requirements of Paragraph 9.2 to Paragraph 9.9.

subparagraph.title: Other cavity penetrations
subparagraph.p: Where penetrations of the wall cladding are wider than the cavity batten spacing, allowance shall be made for air flow between adjacent cavities by leaving a minimum gap of 10 mm between the bottom of the vertical cavity batten and the flashing to the opening.

subparagraph.title: Pipes and service penetrations
subparagraph.p: Pipes and service penetrations shall be made weathertight by using methods shown in Figures 68 and 69. Flashing tape complying with Paragraph 4.3.11, and sealant complying with:

ol.li: Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or
low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.

paragraph.commentary: Where possible, pipe penetrations, meterboxes and similar penetrations should be located in sheltered areas of the building, such as a porch, or be installed behind a weatherproof glazed panel.

subparagraph.title: Inter-storey junctions
subparagraph.p: Inter-storey junctions in claddings over drained cavities shall be formed for walls:

ol.li: Up to a maximum of two storeys or 7 metres in height, as shown for the specific wall claddings in Paragraph 9.2 to Paragraph 9.9, or
Over two storeys or 7 metres by using an inter-storey flashing bridging the drained cavity as shown in Figure 70.

subparagraph.commentary: A drained cavity height is limited to manage the moisture handled by the cavity before it is directed to the outside.

paragraph.title: Windows and doors
paragraph.p: Windows and doors shall comply with the requirements of NZS 4211, and reveals shall comply with NZS 3602. Flashings shall comply with Paragraph 4.0. Window details specific to particular claddings are given in Paragraph 9.2 to Paragraph 9.9. Door details shall be based on window details and shown in Figures 17A-D.

After installation, the flange forming the window or door facing shall have an overlap to the surrounding cladding material or associated back flashings of a) For jambs - 10 mm minimum b) For sills - 8 mm minimum.

subparagraph.title: Scope
subparagraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to aluminium window and door joinery that:

ol.li: Has horizontal window and door heads only
Has maximum frame dimensions of 5000 mm wide or 5000 mm high, and a maximum overall frame area, for any one frame, of 13.5 m2, or
For sills to floor level, has maximum width of 6 m and maximum overall frame area is 16 m2.

subparagraph.commentary: Sloped heads require specifically designed kick-out flashings at bottom edges of head flashings. Where width outlined in Paragraph 9.1.10.1 are beyond the limits for sill and head trimmer framing in NZS 3604 specific engineering design of the framing is required. Certain aluminium joinery sections and installation requirements may not be able to meet the details of this Acceptable Solution, especially in regard to window facing cover, sill support, window fixing, and sill flashing requirements. The window details in these cases require specific design.

ol.li: Treatment of the window openings for direct fixed wall claddings shall be as shown in Figure 72A.

For direct fixed claddings, windows and doors shall have a 5 mm stand-off of the flange to the cladding to allow for air intrusion to the trim cavity for pressure equalisation. Note that this gap is sealed or trimmed down the jambs, but left open along the sill.
Window openings for wall claddings over drained cavities shall be as shown in Figure 72B. Note there shall be no sill flashing.

For cavity fixed claddings, windows and doors shall finish against the cladding, except for flat fibre cement and ply claddings that require a 5 mm stand-off to allow for sealant weather seals between facings and cladding - eg, Figure 116.
Materials for flashings shall be selected from Paragraph 4.0, Table 7, and Table 20.

subparagraph.title: Window and door heads
subparagraph.p: Windows and doors shall include head flashings, finished to the wall underlay as shown in Figure 71, by either using flexible flashing tape, or lapping an additional layer of wall underlay over the upstand. The additional wall underlay shall extend to the top of the wall, or to the nearest lap above, and be lapped under the top layer.

subparagraph.title: Head flashings
subparagraph.p: Head flashings shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.6.1.6 and Table 7, unless specifically shown otherwise, and shall:

ol.li: Direct water to the outside of the wall cladding, and
Finish to the window head with clearance dimensions shown in Figure 71
For direct fixed claddings, have 50 mm bead of sealant installed between cladding and each end of the head flashing

li.p: For wall claddings on cavity walls:

ol.li: incorporate 10 mm turn-ups as stop-ends, terminating at the inside face of the cladding so they do not pass through the cladding, an
permit ventilation of the drained cavities above, by the installation of cavity base closers as shown in Figure 66.
For Very High and Extra High wind zones, have sealant installed between underside of head flashing and top edge of window head flange - refer Figure 71 (c) .

subparagraph.commentary: Stopends are useful to prevent water moving past the ends of head flashings. However, additional problems of weatherproofing occur where the stopend penetrates the cladding.

li.p: Direct fixed claddings shall have

ol.li: sill tray flashings as shown in Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9 for each cladding type. The sill flashing shall extend back past the condensation channel of the window. Ensure flat sill trays do not slope backwards. The 5 mm gap between the window facing and sill tray must not be sealed.
direct fixed door sills, installed as for windows, and as shown in Figure 17D.

li.p: Claddings over a drained cavity shall have:

ol.li: window sills as shown in Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9, without sill flashing
door sills as shown in Figure 17C.

Sill support bars and mechanisms for all doors, and for windows with a trim opening wider than 600 mm. Support bars and mechanisms shall comply with BRANZ Evaluation Method EM6, E2/VM1 and B2/AS1. Support bars and mechanisms must be installed prior to installation of the window or door.

ol.commentary: Support bars and mechanisms are rated for their capacity to support the total weight of a joinery unit when installed at given offsets from the frame depending on cladding type. Designers select the an appropriate complying support mechanism for the joinery weight. Manufacturers provide build-in instructions for support bars and mechanisms.
ol.li: Mitred aluminium window and door sills, for both cavity and direct fixed, shall have a corner soaker fitted to the back of the sill/jamb joint and installed at point of manufacture. The soaker will be designed to act as a secondary device to prevent water ingress to the building in support of the primary mitre seals. Soaker materials shall be either uPVC, aluminium, polypropylene, high impact styrene or other semi rigid moulded polymeric material. Sill support bars and mechanisms must be designed to not impede the possible drainage of water from surfaces of sill flashing tape, and permit an air passage (of at least 1000 mm2/m sill width) from the drained cavity to the window/door trim cavity.

subparagraph.title: Window and door jambs
subparagraph.p: Jamb flashings shall be installed as shown in Paragraphs 9.2 to 9.9. Where required, jamb flashings shall overlap sill flashings, and direct moisture to the outside face of the cladding system.

subparagraph.title: Closed cell foam tape
subparagraph.p: Compressible foam tape shown behind window facings and cladding joints shall be closed cell PVC foam, with:

ol.li: Hardness 55-60 to ASTM D2240 Scale OO,
Grade VE-43 to ASTM D1667,
Compression set of 20% maximum to ASTM D1667, and
UV weathering in UV Weatherometer for 1500 light hours to ASTM G154 or ASTM G155 with no visible deterioration in appearance.

subparagraph.title: Attachments for windows and doors
subparagraph.p: Install windows and doors using pairs of minimum 75 x 3.15 galvanised jolt head nails or 8 gauge x 65 mm stainless steel screws, through reveals into surrounding framing at:

ol.li: Maximum 450 mm centres along sills, jambs and heads, and
Maximum 150 mm from reveal ends.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to masonry veneer cladding attached to timber wall framing outlined in NZS 3604. Masonry veneer is either:

ol.li: Clay brick, or
Concrete brick or block.

paragraph.commentary: Natural stone bricks or blocks may be suitable. However, they are not part of this Acceptable Solution. Refer to the manufacturer's recommendations for specific design information. Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

ol.li: The materials and workmanship of masonry veneer shall be in accordance with SNZ HB 4236 and have a maximum mass of veneer of 220 kg/m2 and minimum veneer thickness of 70 mm
Masonry units shall be laid-up in running bond
Mortar, materials (cement, sand and admixtures) shall comply with NZS 4210
Mortar joints less than 24 hours old shall not be subject to vibration, such as would result from the nailing of interior linings

paragraph.title: Installation
paragraph.p: Masonry veneer construction shall be as shown in Figure 73B, and have:

ol.li: A maximum height of veneer above adjacent finished ground level of 7 m.

A maximum height of veneer of 4.0 m, measured from the top of the concrete masonry wall, foundation wall or slab edge foundation. In the case of a veneer faced concrete block wall or foundation wall height is measured from the top of that wall.
A maximum height of veneer of 5.5 m on a gable end wall.
A minimum wall or panel width of 230 mm.

paragraph.p: Note: The bracing demand for framing supporting masonry veneer is determined from values listed in NZS 3604.
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers

paragraph.title: Flashings

li.p: Sill and head flashings shall be as described in Paragraph 4.3 and be either:

ol.li: 1.5 mm butyl rubber- refer to Paragraph 4.3.9
2 ply asphaltic pliable waterproofing membrane - refer to Paragraph 4.3.10
Pliable polyethylene minimum 0.5 mm thick complying with DPC/DPM Table 23.

li.p: Jamb flashings shall be:

ol.li: 2 ply asphaltic pliable waterproofing membrane complying with AS/NZS 2904
Pliable polyethylene minimum 0.5 mm thick complying with DPC/DPM Table 23.

paragraph.commentary: For further information refer to ASTM C1330 for backing rod material performance.

figure.title: Masonry veneer window and door installation

li.p: Masonry veneer shall be supported by one, or a combination of the following:

ol.li: Concrete of masonry foundation wall
Thickened slab edge footing
Concrete or masonry lower storey wall.
The level of the concrete slab above ground shall comply with Figure 65.
The top of a foundation wall or concrete slab shall be stepped down, so that the surface supporting the veneer is 50 mm or more below the surface supporting the timber framing.

li.p: Provide a damp-proof course to the stepped rebates supporting masonry veneer adjacent to all habitable spaces and garages attached to habitable spaces. This includes stepped rebates in foundations, or on top of concrete or concrete masonry walls supporting veneers. Damp-proofing material shall be as outlined in Table 23 and be either:
For rebates lower than ground floor level:

ol.li: two coats of bituminous liquid, or
1.0 mm butyl rubber or bituminous sheet, or
0.25 mm polythene or polyethylene damp-proof membrane.

li.p: For rebates above ground floor level:

ol.li: 1.0 mm butyl rubber or bituminous sheet, or
0.25 mm polythene or polyethylene damp-proof membrane
Lap joints in flashings minimum of 150 mm.
Dimension rebates to accommodate the required cavity width in Paragraph 9.2.6 and the thickness of the veneer so that the veneer is supported within the tolerances outlined in Figures 73D and E.

paragraph.title: Cavities
paragraph.p: Paragraphs 9.1.8.2(a), 9.1.8.5, and 9.1.9.3 shall apply to masonry veneer cavities.

ol.li: The clear width of cavity between the masonry veneer and the exterior face of the wall underlay or bracing attaching to timber framing shall not be less than 40 mm or more than 75 mm wide measured at any part of the cavity.
ol.commentary: It is important to maintain the minimum cavity width of 40 mm after allowing for construction tolerances and thicknesses of wall underlays and sheet bracing.
ol.li: Pipes and services shall not be placed in the cavity other than passing directly through the cavity to the exterior.

li.p: The cavity shall be drained and vented to outside at the bottom of wall panels, and above openings by open perpends that:

ol.li: are a minimum of 75 mm in height, by the width of the vertical mortar joint
at centres not exceeding 800 mm (where drainage/weep holes are less than 75 mm high, decrease spacing to give a ventilation area of 1000 mm2/m wall length)
are fitted with vermin proofing where gaps greater than 13 mm exist.

The cavity shall be ventilated to the outside at the top of walls by either similar vents as at the bottom, or a continuous 5 mm minimum gap between the top course and soffit board, with a cover bead to outside that maintains a minimum 2 mm gap to masonry - refer to Figure 73E(l).

The cavity shall be vented under openings exceeding 2.4 metres wide through gaps in perpends positioned at 1/3 points along the opening except at opening ends. Where these vent openings are used, protect from water entry using cantilevered sill bricks, as shown in Figure 73C (f).
The cavity shall be sealed off from the floor and roof space.

paragraph.commentary: Variations in cavity width will require compensating adjustments to the length of masonry tie used.

paragraph.title: Wall ties
paragraph.p: Masonry veneer shall be attached to wall framing by wall ties. Wall ties and their spacings and embedment shall be in accordance with the requirements of NZS 4210 and Tables 18A, 18B and 18C. Screw fixings shall be minimum 12 gauge, 35 mm long hex washer face, galvanised or stainless steel to suit the ties required under Table 18C.

subparagraph.p: Wall ties and screws shall be determined by the durability zone outlined in NZS 3604 and as outlined in Table 18C.

subparagraph.title: Clay bricks
subparagraph.p: Control joints in clay brick masonry veneer are not required, unless specified by the brick manufacturer.

subparagraph.title: Concrete bricks
subparagraph.p: Longitudinal shrinkage stresses in concrete masonry veneer shall be controlled by providing vertical control joints at not more than 6 m centres. Vertical control joints shall be located:

ol.li: Within 600 mm of T joints
Within 600 mm of L shaped corners or by restricting the spacing to the next control joint to 3.2 m maximum
At changes in wall height, exceeding 600 mm
At changes in wall thickness.

subparagraph.p: Control joints shall be formed as shown in Figure 73A and comprise: a) A backer rod of compressible foam, and b) Sealant in compliance with: i) Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or ii) low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.

paragraph.title: Openings in masonry veneer
paragraph.p: Openings with masonry veneer above shall be spanned by steel angle lintels. Openings in masonry veneer for meter boxes less than 500 mm wide may be installed without lintel bars or head flashings provided the meter box is sealed to wall underlay with flashing tape to Paragraph 4.3.11. Separate steel meter boxes from direct contact with masonry veneer or mortar with flashing tape to Paragraph 4.3.11. Lintels shall:

ol.li: Be protected against corrosion as in Table 18D and to exposure zones outlined in NZS 3604.

li.p: Have a minimum seating into adjacent veneer of:

ol.li: 100 mm for spans up to, and including 2 m,
200 mm for spans over 2 m.
Be sized in accordance with Table 18E.

subparagraph.title: Windows and doors
subparagraph.p: The openings in wall framing for windows and doors shall have flexible flashing tape applied, in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.5. Air seals shall be provided in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.6. Window flashings shall be installed in accordance with Paragraph 9.2.4 and Figures 73C and 73D(h).

subparagraph.title: Secondary cladding
subparagraph.p: Where a secondary cladding is used with the masonry veneer, and is direct fixed to framing above windows or at gable ends, this shall be fully sealed on:

ol.li: The face of the cladding,
All edges of the cladding, and
A 75 mm minimum perimeter strip on the rear of the cladding.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following types of stucco cladding:

ol.li: Solid plaster cladding with a non-rigid backing and a drained cavity, and
Solid plaster cladding with a rigid backing and a drained cavity. Refer to Figure 74

paragraph.title: Structure
paragraph.p: The timber framing of external walls supporting stucco wall claddings shall comply with NZS 3604 and NZS 4251. The cladding system shall be attached to the wall framing.
The framing for buildings using stucco exterior cladding systems shall be supported on a:

ol.li: Concrete slab-on-ground, or
Continuous reinforced concrete foundation wall, or
Reinforced concrete masonry foundation wall.

paragraph.title: Stucco cladding system
paragraph.p: All stucco claddings shall be used over a drained cavity as described in Paragraph 9.1.8, and shown in Figure 74.

subparagraph.p: All stucco cladding shall have wall underlay as specified in Table 23 and Paragraphs 9.1.5-9.1.7, and shall be:

ol.li: Fixed to the framing as specified in Table 23, and
Provided as an overlay to rigid backings to provide a slip layer that permits the independent movement of plaster and backing.

subparagraph.p: Have plaster backing installed as in Paragraphs 9.3.5 and 9.3.6.
Have metal lath reinforcements for stucco plaster attached through the plaster backing as described in Table 24.

subparagraph.title: General
subparagraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.
subparagraph.p: Activities that will cause impact or vibration during plaster application are not permitted until all plastering is completed and fully cured. The materials, proportions, mixes, thickness, reinforcement materials and fixing, control joints, and application and curing of plaster shall comply with NZS 4251.

subparagraph.title: Movement control joints
subparagraph.p: Movement control joints shall be as required in NZS 4251.

subparagraph.title: Installation of wall underlays
subparagraph.p: The wall underlay shall be in accordance with Table 23, and as described in Paragraphs 9.1.5-9.1.7.

paragraph.title: Rigid plaster backings
paragraph.p: Rigid backings shall be made of either:

ol.li: Plywood, or
Fibre cement sheet, and Have slip layers to Paragraph 9.3.3 b).

paragraph.p: Backing sheets shall be no more than 3 mm out of plane at the time of plastering.

subparagraph.title: Plywood backing
subparagraph.p: Plywood shall be:

ol.li: Selected from Table 6 of NZS 4251,
H3 treated as per AS/NZS 2269, and

li.p: Fixed as specified in Clause 4.2.4.4.2 of NZS 4251, except that nails shall:

ol.li: be 2.8 mm in diameter, and
penetrate framing by 35 mm minimum.

subparagraph.title: Fibre cement sheet backing
subparagraph.p: Fibre cement shall:

ol.li: Comply with AS/NZS 2908: Part 2,
Be a minimum of 4.5 mm thick,
Span no more than 600 mm centres between cavity battens, and

li.p: Be fixed as specified in Clause 4.2.4.5.2 of NZS 4251, except that nails shall:

ol.li: be 2.8 mm in diameter, and
penetrate framing by 35 mm minimum.

subparagraph.commentary: When the sheathing is used as bracing, the nailing patterns are subject to specific design, and the use of tested and rated systems.

paragraph.title: Finishes
paragraph.p: All stucco surfaces shall be sealed by applying a minimum of a 2-coat latex exterior paint system complying with any of Parts 7, 8, 9 or 10 of AS 3730.
paragraph.commentary: Stucco cladding systems cannot be assumed to be completely weatherproof. It is necessary to ensure that corrosive salts are not carried into the plaster by moisture, causing corrosion of the reinforcing and fixings.

paragraph.title: Bottom of stucco
paragraph.p: The bottom of stucco wall cladding shall be in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.3, and as shown in Figure 75.

paragraph.title: Parapets and enclosed balustrades
paragraph.p: Parapets shall be in accordance with Paragraph 6.0. Enclosed balustrades shall be in accordance with Paragraph 7.4. Parapets and enclosed balustrades for stucco cladding shall be capped with metal, butyl or EPDM membrane, complying with the requirements of Paragraph 4.0.

paragraph.title: Windows and doors
paragraph.p: Windows and doors shall comply with Paragraph 9.1.10, as shown in Figure 76.

figure.title: Windows and doors in stucco cladding

section.title: Timber Weatherboards
section.p: Timber weatherboard claddings shall be either direct fixed to framing over a wall underlay or fixed over a drained cavity as described in Paragraph 9.1.8.
Based on the risk score for an external wall calculated as per Paragraph 3.1, the weatherboard cladding may require the inclusion of a drained cavity.

subparagraph.title: Weatherboard profiles
subparagraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following types of timber weatherboards:

ol.li: Horizontal bevel-back,
Horizontal rebated bevel-back,
Horizontal rusticated,
Vertical shiplap, and
Vertical board and batten.

subparagraph.p: Profiles shall be as given in NZS 3617 or BRANZ Bulletin 411.

subparagraph.title: Vertical weatherboards
subparagraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the use of direct fixed vertical weatherboards in risk categories as shown in Table 3.
subparagraph.commentary: Vertical weatherboards are not used over cavities because of the need for horizontal battens, which if solid would interfere with a drained cavity. Vertical weatherboards are therefore limited to low risk applications.

subparagraph.title: Horizontal weatherboards
subparagraph.p: Horizontal weatherboards shall be either direct fixed or fixed over a drained cavity, according to the risk categories as shown in Table 3.

paragraph.title: Materials
paragraph.p: Timber weatherboard cladding shall include the following features:

ol.li: Wall underlay complying with Table 23 and Paragraphs 9.1.5-9.1.7, and
Timber selection and treatment of weatherboards in accordance with NZS 3602.

paragraph.title: Installation
paragraph.p: A building underlay complying with Table 23 shall be installed behind:

ol.li: All direct fixed timber weatherboards, or
Cavity battens for timber weatherboards installed over a drained cavity.

paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

subparagraph.title: Fixings
subparagraph.p: Fixings shall comply with Tables 20 and 24.
Timber weatherboards shall be drilled for nailing at all joints and ends. All cut ends of painted weatherboards shall be primed.

subparagraph.title: Horizontal laps
subparagraph.p: Laps shall be:

ol.li: 32 mm for non-rebated bevel-back boards, or
25 mm horizontal lap for rebated bevel-back and rusticated boards, with a minimum gap of 2 mm at the overlap between boards.

subparagraph.title: Joints
subparagraph.p: Joints shall be made only over supports and have:

ol.li: Corrosion-resistant soakers fitted, complying with Paragraph 4.3.2 to Paragraph 4.3.8, or
Scarf or splay joints.

subparagraph.title: Fixings
subparagraph.p: Boards shall be fixed through the wall underlay to the framing in accordance with Table 24.

subparagraph.title: External corners
subparagraph.p: External corners shall be weatherproofed by one of the following methods:

li.p: For rusticated and bevel-back weatherboards, corner boxes with:

ol.li: scribers for bevel-back weatherboards, as shown in Figure 78, or
plugs or scribers for rusticated weatherboards, as shown in Figure 78,

li.p: For bevel-back weatherboards:

ol.li: mitred joints with back flashing as shown in Figure 78, or
mitred joints with corrosion-resistant soakers - refer to Paragraphs 4.3.2 to 4.3.6 and Figure 77.

subparagraph.title: Internal corners
subparagraph.p: Internal corners shall be made weathertight as shown in Figure 79. A corrosion-resistant flashing shall be fitted behind weatherboards at all internal corners as shown in Figure 79.

figure.title: Internal corners for horizontal or vertical weatherboards

paragraph.title: Vertical weatherboards
paragraph.p: Vertical shiplap and board and batten weather-boards shall be in continuous lengths over a storey height.

ol.li: Vertical shiplap weatherboards shall be fitted with a minimum gap of 2 mm at the overlap between boards.

li.p: Board and batten weatherboards shall:

ol.li: be fitted with a 5 mm to 8 mm gap between boards, and
have weather grooves to boards and battens aligned.

subparagraph.title: Fixings
subparagraph.p: Vertical weatherboards shall be fixed to dwangs at 480 mm maximum centres in accordance with Table 24.

ol.li: External corners - External corners shall be weatherproofed by the use of corner facings as shown in Figure 80.
Internal corners - A corrosion-resistant corner flashing, as per Table 7 and Figure 79, shall be fitted behind the weatherboards at all internal corners.

paragraph.title: Windows and doors in direct fixed weatherboards
paragraph.p: Window and door details for:

ol.li: Direct fixed bevel-back weatherboards are shown in Figure 81,
Direct fixed rusticated weatherboards are shown in Figure 82,
Vertical shiplap weatherboards are shown in Figure 83,
Vertical board and batten weatherboards are shown in Figure 84.

paragraph.p: Door sill details are as shown in Figure 17D.

paragraph.title: Windows and doors in cavity walls
paragraph.p: Window and door details for bevel-back weatherboards on a drained cavity shall be as shown in Figure 85. Window and door details for rusticated weatherboards on a drained cavity are shown in Figure 86. Door sill details are as shown in Figure 17C.
paragraph.commentary: The junctions around windows are critical, and it is important that responsibility is taken for the weathertightness of the window as installed within exterior walls. Care should be taken to ensure that this responsibility is clearly defined and assigned. One way is to clearly specify that the window manufacturer shall be responsible for the supply and installation of flashings and frames into openings.

Windows and doors for direct fixed vertical shiplap weatherboards
Windows and doors for direct fixed board and batten weatherboards
Windows and doors for bevel-back weatherboards on cavity
Windows and doors for rusticated weatherboards on cavity

paragraph.title: Parapets and enclosed balustrades
paragraph.p: Parapets shall be in accordance with Paragraph 6.0.
Enclosed balustrades shall be in accordance with Paragraph 7.4.

paragraph.title: Finishes
paragraph.p: Where a protective finish is required by NZS 3602, all timber surfaces, including end grain and laps, shall be sealed by priming.
Two coats of exterior grade paint shall be applied, after priming, to all exposed surfaces. Paint systems shall comply with any of Parts 7, 8, 9 or 10 of AS 3730.
paragraph.commentary: The minimum durability period for protective coatings is 5 years. Improvement in durability and stability of weatherboards can be achieved by priming all surfaces including backs of boards. Manufacturers of coatings which have a proven performance in use may be able to show compliance with NZBC B2 Durability as detailed in B2/VM1 as an alternative to compliance with AS 3730. With tangentially-sawn weatherboards, particularly painted or stained in dark colours, cupping is possible. Providing additional fixings may help restrain the board, but will usually result in splitting of the boards.

section.title: Fibre Cement Weatherboards
section.p: Fibre cement weatherboard claddings shall be either direct fixed to framing over a wall underlay, or fixed over a drained cavity as described in Paragraph 9.1.8.
Based on the risk score for an external wall, calculated as per Paragraph 3.1, the fibre cement weatherboard cladding may require the inclusion of a drained cavity.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to flat fibre cement weatherboards, with a minimum thickness of 7.5 mm.

paragraph.title: Material performance
paragraph.p: Fibre cement weatherboards shall comply with AS/NZS 2908: Part 2.

paragraph.title: Installation
paragraph.p: A wall underlay, as specified in Table 23 and Paragraphs 9.1.5-9.1.7, shall be installed behind fibre cement weatherboard claddings.
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

subparagraph.title: Fixings
subparagraph.p: Fibre cement weatherboards shall be fixed through the wall underlay to the framing at maximum 600 mm centres as per Table 24.

subparagraph.title: Laps and joints
subparagraph.p: Horizontal laps shall be a minimum of 30 mm. Joints shall be:

ol.li: Positioned between studs,
Staggered at a minimum of 600 mm from joints in the adjacent boards, and

li.p: Weatherproofed by:

ol.li: uPVC H jointers as shown in Figure 87, or

li.p: hidden soakers as shown in Figure 87, with sealant used between ends of boards complying with:

ol.li: Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or
low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C.

subparagraph.title: External corners
subparagraph.p: External corners shall be weatherproofed as shown in Figure 88 by:

ol.li: The use of corrosion-resistant soakers complying with Paragraph 4.2.2 to Paragraph 4.3.6, or
Facings with weathergrooves.

subparagraph.title: Internal corners
subparagraph.p: Internal corners shall be weatherproofed by metal corner flashings as shown in Figure 89.

paragraph.title: Windows and doors
paragraph.p: Windows and doors shall be installed in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.10.

subparagraph.title: Windows and doors - direct fixed
subparagraph.p: For direct fixed fibre cement weatherboards, windows and doors shall be detailed as shown in Figure 90 and Figure 17D.

subparagraph.title: Windows - on cavity
subparagraph.p: For fibre cement weatherboards fixed over a drained cavity, windows and doors shall be detailed as shown in Figure 91 and Figure 17C.

paragraph.title: Parapets and enclosed balustrades
paragraph.p: Parapets shall be in accordance with Paragraph 6.0. Enclosed balustrades shall be in accordance with Paragraph 7.4.

paragraph.title: Protective coating
paragraph.p: The exposed faces, including top edges at sills and all bottom edges, of horizontal fibre cement weatherboards shall be finished with a minimum of a 2-coat latex exterior paint system complying with any of Parts 7, 8, 9 or 10 of AS 3730.

section.title: Profiled Metal Wall Cladding
section.p: Horizontal profiled metal wall cladding shall be fixed over a drained cavity as described in Paragraph 9.1.8.
Vertical profiled metal wall cladding shall be direct fixed to framing over a roof underlay.
Refer to Table 3: Suitable wall claddings.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to corrugated or trapezoidal metal wall cladding with the profiles, as shown in Figure 38, and applied as outlined in Table 3.

paragraph.title: General
paragraph.commentary: Refer to Paragraph 1.5 for qualification of installers.

paragraph.title: Materials

subparagraph.title: Choice of metal
subparagraph.p: The metal cladding shall be selected according to the exposure conditions in Table 20 as defined in:

ol.li: NZS 3604, or
AS/NZS 2728.

subparagraph.commentary: The exposure zone in which a building is located can affect the durability of flashings. Exposure zones are defined in NZS 3604, based on the likely exposure to wind-driven sea-salt. Corrosion due to geothermal or corrosive industrial atmospheres, as defined in NZS 3604, requires specific design. Exposure zones are based on AS/NZS 2728. AS/NZS 2728 lists atmospheric classes derived from ISO 9223 for Australia and New Zealand.

subparagraph.title: Steel
subparagraph.p: Materials for the manufacture of profiled steel cladding shall:

ol.li: Have a BMT of 0.4 mm minimum,
Be grade G550, or G300 for curved and crimped cladding
Be selected for corrosion protection according to the intended exposure zone as shown in Table 20.

subparagraph.title: Aluminium
subparagraph.p: Aluminium for the manufacture of profiled aluminium wall cladding shall comply with AS/NZS 1734, and be:

ol.li: A base metal thickness (BMT) of a minimum of 0.7 mm,
Minimum 5000 series.

paragraph.p: For pre-painted aluminium, a factory-applied finish complying with AS/NZS 2728 shall be applied.

paragraph.title: Maintenance
paragraph.p: Refer to Paragraph 2.5.

paragraph.title: Profiles
paragraph.p: Profiles covered in this Acceptable Solution are:

ol.li: Corrugated - curved with a minimum crest height of 16.5 mm minimum, and
Trapezoidal - symmetrical and asymmetrical with a minimum crest height of 19 mm.

paragraph.p: For details of these profiles, refer to Figure 38.

paragraph.title: Fixing
paragraph.p: The cladding shall be screw-fixed through the troughs and battens, where applicable, into the framing. Fixings shall:

ol.li: Be minimum 12-gauge hexagonal head, self-drilling wood screws,
Penetrate the framing by a minimum of 30 mm,
Be minimum Class 4 to AS 3566: Part 2, selected from Table 20,
Include neoprene (having a carbon black content of 15% or less by weight) or EPDM sealing washers as shown in Figure 39, and

li.p: Be used on the cladding at side laps and every second trough or, for trapezoidal where the rib centres exceed 150 mm, at side laps and every trough:

ol.li: to framing, and
at all external and internal corners.

paragraph.title: Flashings
paragraph.p: Flashings used with metal wall cladding shall be in accordance with Paragraph 4.0, and with the following requirements:

ol.li: Hooks and hems shall be as shown in Figure 5,
Have joints formed with laps and sealant as shown in Figure 6,

li.p: Where shown, sealant shall be neutral cure, complying with:

ol.li: Type F, Class 20LM or 25LM of ISO 11600, or
low modulus Type II Class A of Federal Specification TT-S-00230C,
Under-flashings shall be fixed to framing at 600 mm maximum centres.

li.p: Flashings shall be fixed together at junctions at 50 mm maximum centres or to cladding at 900 mm centres with:

ol.li: for galvanized steel, 4 mm diameter monel metal or stainless steel rivets, where compatible as per Table 21, or
for aluminium-zinc coated steel, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets, or
for aluminium, 4 mm diameter aluminium rivets.

subparagraph.title: Installation
subparagraph.p: For direct fixed vertical profile, the wall underlay shall be in accordance with the properties listed for roof underlay in Table 23.
For copper-based treated framing or underlay refer to Paragraph 9.6.9.2.
subparagraph.commentary: In direct fixed metal cladding, the wall underlay will be in contact with the back of the vertical profiled metal cladding. Underlay is needed to separate treated timber from the back of the metal to minimise the risk of electrolytic corrosion.

subparagraph.title: Barges
subparagraph.p: Barge flashings shall be as shown in Figure 92.

subparagraph.title: Bottom of cladding
subparagraph.p: The bottom edge of the cladding shall overlap the foundation wall as described in Paragraph 9.1.3 and as shown in Figure 93.

figure.title: Bottom of cladding for vertical profiled metal

subparagraph.title: Corners
subparagraph.p: Direct fixed vertical profiled metal wall cladding shall be over-flashed at external and internal corners as shown in Figure 94. The cover of the flashings shall:

ol.li: Be dimensioned to suit the metal wall cladding profile,
Cover at least two crests for corrugated and single crests for other profiles, and
Terminate as shown in Figure 93

subparagraph.title: Vertical profile: penetrations
subparagraph.p: Pipe penetrations shall be as per Figure 53. The heads of larger penetrations shall be flashed in similar fashion to Figure 69, with head flashings adjusted to suit the profile and other flashings as per window and door details in relevant paragraphs.

subparagraph.title: Vertical profile: windows and doors
subparagraph.p: Windows and doors in vertical profiled metal claddings shall be flashed as shown in Figure 95 and Figure 100.

figure.title: Windows and doors for vertical profiled metal

subparagraph.title: Installation
subparagraph.p: A wall underlay, as specified in Table 23 and Paragraphs 9.1.5-9.1.7, shall be installed over the outside face of the framing.

subparagraph.title: Cavity battens
subparagraph.p: If the cavity batten contains copper (e.g. CCA, copper azole or ACQ), appropriate separation between the back of the cladding and the cavity batten shall be provided.
Examples of suitable separation are:

ol.li: An additional layer of paper-based underlay, complying with Table 23, over cavity battens,
Strips of paper-based underlay complying with Table 23 on the face of cavity battens,
Pre-priming cavity battens.

figure.title: Corner flashings for horizontal profiled metal

subparagraph.title: Corners
subparagraph.p: Corners shall be weatherproofed by using the flashings and details shown in Figure 96. Horizontal profiled metal wall cladding shall be under-flashed using butt flashings which shall:

ol.li: Be formed in one shaped piece,
Allow metal cladding to butt, with a separation of 5 mm, against sides of the exposed flashing corner, and
Use profiled compressible foam to seal between the flashing underlap and underside of cladding.

subparagraph.title: Barges
subparagraph.p: Barge flashings shall be as shown in Figure 97.

subparagraph.title: Bottom of cladding
subparagraph.p: The bottom edge of the cladding shall overlap the foundation wall as described in Paragraph 9.1.3 and as shown in Figure 98.

subparagraph.title: Horizontal profile: penetrations
subparagraph.p: All services penetrations through claddings shall be flashed and sealed. Pipe penetrations are shown in Figure 53.
The heads of larger penetrations shall be flashed in a similar fashion to Figure 69.

subparagraph.title: Horizontal profile: windows and doors
subparagraph.p: Windows and doors shall be installed in accordance with Paragraph 9.1.10, and as shown in Figure 99 and Figure 100.

subparagraph.title: Parapets and balustrades
subparagraph.p: Refer to Figures 101 and 102 for horizontal and vertical profiled metal. Parapets shall be in accordance with Paragraph 6.0. Enclosed balustrades shall comply with Paragraph 7.4.
subparagraph.commentary: Side fixings of handrails or other attachments to enclosed balustrades or parapets will require specific design to demonstrate weathertightness, together with specific structural design for stanchion fixings.

Window and door flashings for profiled metal
Balustrade and parapet for vertical profiled metal
Balustrade and parapet for horizontal profiled metal

section.title: Fibre Cement Sheet
section.p: Fibre cement sheet claddings shall be either direct fixed to framing over a wall underlay or fixed over a drained cavity based on the risk score for an external wall, calculated as per Paragraph 3.1 and Table 3.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution is limited to the following types of fibre cement sheet cladding systems:

li.p: Flush-finished systems over a drained cavity using sheets of 7.5 mm minimum thickness, with

ol.li: fibre cement sheets manufactured with a rebated edge for this purpose,
if necessary for part sheets, rebated on site using a purpose-made tool, and
have all edges sealed,
joints, comprising a bedding compound and reinforcing tape, that are finished in accordance with Paragraph 9.7.10.4, or

li.p: Jointed systems in accordance with Paragraph 9.7.3 using sheets of 6 mm minimum thickness with:

ol.li: purpose-made jointers,
timber battens over joints.

paragraph.title: Material and installation - both systems
paragraph.p: Fibre cement shall comply with AS/NZS 2908: Part 2.

subparagraph.title: Installation

section.title: Plywood Sheet
section.p: Plywood-sheet claddings shall be either direct fixed to framing over a wall underlay or fixed over a drained cavity as per Paragraph 9.1.8.
Based on the risk score for an external wall, calculated as per Paragraph 3.1, the sheet cladding may require the inclusion of a drained cavity.

paragraph.title: Limitations
paragraph.p: This Acceptable Solution covers plywood panel claddings with vertical battened joints and flashed horizontal joints.

paragraph.title: Installation
